Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 10:26AM IllinoisNancy wrote: Hi, My last chemo is March 16th, which completes 20 weeks and I'm scheduled for surgery on April 6th.  I think 3 weeks is the standard for timeframe based on what I read.  I'm really nervous about the surgery but anxious to finish chemo.  It has been awful!!  I'm gettine a BMX in hopes that I  never have to go through this again.  I was treated for stage I chemo in October of 06.  I was doing great on Tamoxifen for 4 years, no real se...and then the tumors came back on the same breast.  Needless to say, I wish I would of had a masectomy the first time.  I also have 4 small spots on the outside of the breast which are ILC too.  Please throw everything you can at this stuff.  It is sneaky and grows back even while taking anti-hormone pills.  Good luck!

Posts.Title: Stable for Christmas DivineMrsM GatorGal

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 04:16PM IllinoisNancy wrote: Hi Nancy, I know how you are feeling. I had my (10th routine) annual mammogam with a ultrasound and biopsy immediatley following all on a Friday.  The radiologist wouldn't let me leave until he had all the samples and photos he needed. I worreid all weekend and then got the news that it was cancer. When the doctor took my biopsy, he looked me in the eyes and said he thinks it looks like cancer.  The lab that checked my biopsy at the local facility said I had IDC but when I got to the surgeon and a bigger lab they said ILC.  It really doesn't matter which one because they treat them the same.  Anyway....34 radiation treatments later and 3 years of Tamoxifen under my belt, I'm happy to say I'm doing great.  I think the part you are in is the worst but it will get better...trust me:) Have faith in the doctors and try not to stress. I would recommend a Xanex or something to help you relax. I took Lexapro and Xanax in the early days and now I'm happier than I've ever been and living and loving life like I never did before. Take care, Nancy

Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 11:53AM IllinoisNancy wrote: Hi Robyn, Sorry you have to join us but very happy to hear from you.  I have ILC also so we can really relate.  My ILC came back after they thought it was gone 4 years ago.  It is very sneaky which is why I'm having a BMX even though my right breast has never had a problem. I wish you well with your decision.  Only you can know what is right for you.  Pam, I just got back from my tests and everything went well.  I was in and out in an hour.  Now I just need to get thru tomorrows last chemo and the Neulasta shot on Thurs.  It seems like I have been on chemo for a year!!  Hope you all have a great day!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 09:06AM IllinoisNancy wrote: Hi, Checking in with all of you. Surgery is over, 3 nights in hospital, did full reconstruction so no TE's which was a big surprise, nodes looked good so they did not take any, right side was clear of all cancer and healing well, LAT flap cut on back is very sore but healing, Left breast is not doing as well as I expected.  Took most of the skin but could not take it all.  Radiated skin is healing very slowly, very black in color.  ILC was still found in left breast but BS expected that (I had hoped for other results). Chemo had erased if from the skin but not from behind the nipple where it was hiding.  Came home with  4 drains and a big pain tube bulb.  Since then I have had the pain bulb tubes removed and one drain tube so I'm down to 3.  Husband has been draining and recording amounts so I think I will get one more out today.  I will need to have two in for the weekend and aleast until Tuesday when I have my next appointment.  This has been much harder than I thought.  Non radiated skin is wonderful.....radiated skin is bad.  If I had it all to do over since 2006, I would never had a lumpectomy with rads.  I would have gone for the full masectomy.  Healing would be so much easier.  Hope all of you are doing well.  I feel battered and beaten.  BC is really horrible and I hate it more with each passing day. Nancy
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2011 10:30AM IllinoisNancy wrote: Hi, I had a second surgery last Thursday to cut away the dead skin from radiation 4 years ago.  I am healing much better physically now.  I cry and hurt emotionally and don't know how to think positive anymore.  I'm sorry we are all going through this.  I see both surgeons tomorrow and my ongologist on Wednesday to find out what is next.  I think having cancer come back after 4 years is much harder than the first time.  I just want to hear about others who have had this and have a happy life after the second treatment.  Sorry to ramble but I'M SCARED. Nancy

Take care, Nancy

Posts.Title: Oncotype DX 16 gj60 san4850

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2007 12:20PM - edited Nov 14, 2007 12:21PM by IllinoisNancy My name was blacked out but you could still see through the marks that it had my name, DOB and date of surgery correct.  I scored a 9 so my oncologist said, "no chemo".  He didn't even entertain the idea.  My cancer was ILC, 1.1 cm, no nodes, clean margins except for a few scattered cytokeratin positive single cells which made me nervous.  The doctor said it was probably a result of the surgery spreading the cells a little but chemo wasn't necessary.  I am doing great and taking Tamoxifen since I finished rads.  I think I will change to Armidex next year and continue with that for 5 years.

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 03:04PM IllinoisNancy wrote: Dear Sister, Stage IV is far from a death sentence.  I have a friend who was diagnosed with breast cancer when she gave birth to her son and lived to watch him graduate from high school.  She had it in her breasts, bones, brain and eventually liver. She was stage IV for 16 years.  Don't let your sister give up.  There are lots of good treatments today. ((Hugs)) Nancy

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 07:01PM IllinoisNancy wrote: Hi, I have been getting a Neulasta shot exactly 24 hours after chemo for my first AC treatments.  The shot makes my bones ache but my white blood count is higher than ever all the time.  My blood count is usually 13 or 14.  I think the Neulasta really works. Nancy

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 10:53PM IllinoisNancy wrote: Hi Ashley, Hope you had a good check up today.  To answer your question, no the spots never got bigger and I had pain in my chest just like you mention.  I know that doesn't mean that it's cancer but I would certainly get it checked out with a specialist.  Breast cancer is always better to catch in early stages. Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2011 08:21PM IllinoisNancy wrote: My oncologist always does blood tests and xrays every six months.  That was the first four years when I was stage 1.  Now that I've entered stage 3, I'm not sure what the routine will be.  My recurrence was found by a breast surgeon during an annual exam.  The mammogram was perfect and didn't show a thing.  ILC has a way of hiding from almost everything.

Posts.Title: Chemo Brain Ok, but chemo vagina? Help!!!! Shanagirl BlondiShanagirl

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 11:28AM IllinoisNancy wrote: I am going thru my second breast cancer which is classified as a "recurrence" of ILC as a result of two biopsies.  It is not IBC nor is it mets.  It is simply the same type of cancer I had the last time, ILC, ER+, PR-, HER-, BRCA was negative along with another genetic test called PALB2 Gene Mutation which is new and expensive.  My Onco was thrilled that my insurance authorized payment.  It showed up as 3 small pink bumps on the breast skin which were smaller than misquito bites.  I also had two small tumors show up under the nipple and they are not pagets disease.  I have had MRI's that did not show the outside tumors and a PET scan which did not show anything except for the ones behind the nipple and a mammogram which was all clear and did not detect anything wrong at all.  If it had not been for the BS's routine yearly checkup, no one would have detected my cancer.  I had the oncotype dx the first time after a lumpectomy and it gave me a score of 9 which is very low.  I had a 96% chance of not ever getting it back.  I had 34 radiation treatments followed by 4 years of Tamoxifen which failed me.  I also  had a test after one year of Tamoxifen which confirmed that I was metabolizing it properly.  I'm not over weight, I breast fed my two kids that I had in my 20's for one year each.  My mom is 90 and has never had BC nor any other kind of cancer.  I don't fit the profile for BC but I sure got it TWICE.   My advise to you is to ask a lot of questions and let them test you for everything.  Also make sure you have an experienced breast surgeon examine you carefully.  Then you will know what you have and how you need to be treated.  I am going thru 20 weeks of chemo and my last one is tomorrow.  It is all bad but it beats the alternative.  Good luck! Nancy

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 02:17PM IllinoisNancy wrote: I was dx in 10/06 with ILC, Stage I, 1.1 cm, ER+, PR-, HER2-.  I had  a lumpectomy followed by rads and now Tamoxifen.  I'm 50 and perimenopausal.  My oncologist, surgeon and radiologist all said no to chemo when my Oncotypedx was a 9.  It has been one year since dx and I feel great.   I have lost 15 pounds since dx since I have decided to eat right and exercise.  I guess we need to keep the faith and trust our doctors.  Good luck to all of you!

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 12:49PM IllinoisNancy wrote: I have had BC twice and I hate milk.  I think I got my first BC from 19 years of birth control pills and eating beef and drinking beer.  I have always been thin and exercised.  I think my second BC is because I didn't get chemo the first time.  I also received radiation from a little local hospital and I'm not sure they did it right.  I'm hoping this time with chemo and a bilaterial masectomy I leave nothing behind and can get my life back. Good luck, Nancy
